name: Elementary Arabic I
desc: First semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes Arabic script, basic grammar and vocabulary, and culturally relevant activities.

name: Elementary Arabic II
desc: Second semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes expanded grammar and vocabulary and culturally relevant activities.

name: Conversational Arabic Abroad
desc: Conversational course introducing one of the major dialects of Arabic. Only offered within the context of a University faculty-led study abroad program in the Arab world.

name: Introduction to Arab Cultures
desc: Introduction to the cultures of the Arab world and of the Arabs in diasporas: art, literature, film, music, dance, food, history, religion, folklore, etc.

name: Arabic Literature through the Ages
desc: Introduces the rich literary heritage of the Arabic language from pre-Islamic to modern times and covers major genres. Emphasis on critical thinking, literary analysis, and academic writing.

name: Intermediate Arabic I
desc: Third semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes expanded grammar and vocabulary, and culturally relevant activities.

name: Intermediate Arabic II
desc: Fourth semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes expanded grammar and vocabulary, and culturally relevant activities.

name: Medicine and Modernity in the Arab World
desc: This course introduces students to questions of medicine and modernity in the Arab world from the 19th century to the present. It takes medicine as a lens for understanding the formation of the modern Arab world, connecting medical practices and institutions with wider formations like colonialism, nationalism, violence, or religion.

name: Introduction to the Languages of Morocco
desc: This English-language course introduces students to the sociolinguistic and cultural developments that shape the linguistic map of Morocco. It also analyzes the speakers' attitudes toward the use of the different linguistic varieties (Arabic, Moroccan, French, Spanish, Tamazight) and their pragmatic reasons for activating them.

name: Contemporary Moroccan Literature
desc: This course introduces students to key aspects of Moroccan history, society, and culture through literary and cinematic texts produced since the country's independence. The close reading of these works helps students engage with the social, economic, cultural, and political transformations that have shaped modern Morocco.

name: Arabic Grammar and Composition
desc: Intensive grammar review and composition to improve accuracy and develop writing skills in Modern Standard Arabic.

name: Introduction to Qur'anic Arabic
desc: A text-based course for students interested in acquiring a foundation in the language of the Qur'an and cultural aspects related to it. Chapters of Qur'an will be presented and analyzed; vocabulary and grammatical structures will be discussed and activated; and cultural aspects of the Qur'an will be introduced through Arabic readings, audio, and video.

name: Advanced Arabic I
desc: Fifth semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes intensive reading of a variety of texts; films, oral presentations, and writing; extensive vocabulary development.

name: Advanced Arabic II
desc: Sixth semester of Arabic language instruction, comprising both Modern Standard Arabic and one spoken dialect. Coursework includes intensive reading of a variety of texts; films, oral presentations, and writing; extensive vocabulary development.

name: Arabic Languages across the Curriculum Recitation
desc: Arabic recitation offered in conjunction with selected content courses. Weekly discussion and readings in Arabic relating to attached content courses.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 8 total credits. 8 total completions.

name: Borders and Walls in the Arab World
desc: Can art, film, and literature undo cultural, social, and political divisions created by borders and walls in the Arab world?

name: Women and Leadership in the Arab World
desc: A service-learning, study abroad course focusing on women and leadership in the Arab world. Topics include women and religion, family, community and selfhood, citizenship and legal rights, and politics.

name: Science and Society in the Middle East
desc: This class explores science and society in the modern Middle East. Drawing on works from anthropology and history, it investigates how science interacts with, is shaped by, and reflects wider processes and formations such as nationalism, colonialism, religion, subject formation, or cultural production.

name: Readings in Arabic I
desc: Classical and/or modern readings in Arabic and discussions in conversational Arabic, according to the students' interest.

name: Readings in Arabic II
desc: Classical and/or modern readings in Arabic and discussions in conversational Arabic, according to the students' interest.

name: Modern Arabic Literature in Translation
desc: Course treats a variety of themes and genres of Arabic literature from the mid-20th century to the present.

name: Film, Nation, and Identity in the Arab World
desc: Introduction to history of Arab cinema from 1920s to present. Covers film industries in various regions of the Arab world and transnational Arab film. All materials and discussion in English.

name: Independent Readings in Arabic
desc: Permission of the department. For the student who wishes to create and pursue an independent project in Arabic under the supervision of a selected instructor. Maximum three credit hours per semester.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 12 total credits. 4 total completions.

name: Readings in Islamicate Literatures
desc: Permission of the instructor. Study of selected religious, literary, and historical texts in Arabic, Persian, or Urdu.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.
